qas.question: In 1924, what was created as part of Uzbekistan?

answers.text: collectivization of agriculture and a rapid expansion of cotton production took place

qas.question: Where was the expansion of cotton and agriculture mainly?

answers.text: Soviet collectivization policy brought violence against peasants and forced resettlement

plausible_answers.text: the Tajik Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic

qas.question: Between 1917 and what year did collectivization of agriculture occur?
What policy brought violence against the rich?
What movement was revived by the rich?
Which predominately ethnic Tajik cities did not remain in the Uzbek SSR?

context: In 1924, <b4_0>the <a0_0>Tajik Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic<b4_0/><a0_0/> was created as a part of Uzbekistan, but in 1929 the Tajik Soviet Socialist Republic (Tajik SSR) was made a separate constituent republic, however the predominantly ethnic Tajik cities of <b8_0>Samarkand and Bukhara<b8_0/> remained in the Uzbek SSR. Between 1927 and <b5_0>1934<b5_0/>, <a1_0>collectivization of agriculture and a rapid expansion of cotton production took place<a1_0/>, especially <a2_0>in the southern region<a2_0/>. <a3_0><b6_0>Soviet collectivization<b6_0/> policy brought violence against peasants and forced resettlement<a3_0/> occurred throughout Tajikistan. Consequently, some peasants fought collectivization and revived <b7_0>the Basmachi movement<b7_0/>. Some small scale industrial development also occurred during this time along with the expansion of irrigation infrastructure.
